They have been here for months, and the Council has given them nothing but theological debates about the Filioque clause and the nature of the Holy Spirit's procession. They are desperate, Your Majesty. And desperation makes men both grateful and suspicious. They remember 1204. They remember that the last time Latin armies came to 'help' Constantinople, those armies sacked the city and established a Latin emperor on the Byzantine throne. Whatever you offer them, they will wonder what you want in return.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Papal supremacy. Your Majesty, you say you have come to argue for this, but you must understand—you stand in a Council that has already declared itself superior to the Pope. They invoke the decrees of Constance. They claim that a general council, representing the universal Church, holds authority over any individual, including the Bishop of Rome. The French delegation would cheer if Eugenius were deposed tomorrow. If you stand before this assembly and proclaim papal supremacy, you will not convince them. You will confirm their suspicion that you are the Pope's creature, sent to undermine their legitimate reforms. You will lose whatever influence Castile has built.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: The Hussites. Yes, you have been warned of their military power, and wisely so. But there is more. The moderate Hussites here at Basel—the Utraquists, they call themselves—are not the radicals. The radicals remain in Bohemia, suspicious of any negotiation. The moderates want peace. They want their reforms recognized. They are willing to compromise on some matters. But the Church property question is not theological for them—it is political. Bohemian nobles seized those lands. Those nobles now hold power in Bohemia. Any settlement that demands property return means those nobles lose power, which means civil war in Bohemia, which means the moderates here cannot deliver what they promise. You speak of ending heresy and preventing theft. Noble goals. But ending heresy requires Bohemian cooperation, and preventing theft requires Bohemian nobles to surrender their gains. These goals may be mutually exclusive.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: And finally—you say the Pope has given you authority to speak on his behalf. Your Majesty, forgive an old man's bluntness, but has he? I have seen no letter to the Council. No formal announcement. No papal bull declaring Juan of Castile as legate or representative. You have his blessing, yes. His trust, certainly. But when you stand before Cardinal Cesarini and the assembled fathers and claim to speak for Rome, they will ask: by what authority? A private conversation in the Vatican is not the same as formal appointment. If you overstate your mandate, you will be seen as presumptuous. If you understate it, you will be seen as powerless. Which role do you intend to play?

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: I do not say these things to discourage you, Your Majesty. Your presence here matters. Granada's completion matters. But you have weeks, not months. You cannot solve what this Council has failed to solve in over a year. So I ask again, more precisely: of these four goals, which matters most? And what would success look like for you, knowing the constraints you face?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I show him the papal decree and section four specifically. I am not an official papal legate, but I do speak with his blessing and support. This is all put in writing. I will meet with the Utraquists and see if I can settle them the matter theologically. If I can get them to back down, returning church property becomes a matter between the individual nobles and the church. They have just seized lands unjustly. Could this work do you think? Has the council of Constance actually established consular supremacy? I am confused. I thought that this matter was not established. Tell me. I will listen to the Byzantines first before saying anything. I want to hear their position.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott took the decree carefully, his aged eyes squinting at the Latin script in the fading light. He read Article Four slowly, lips moving slightly as he absorbed each phrase. When he finished, he set the document down with visible respect.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: This is more than I expected. His Holiness speaks of 'complete confidence' and 'apostolic blessing.' He declares your witness is testimony the Council fathers 'must hear.' This is not formal legation, no—but it is substantial. It gives you ground to stand upon.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Show this to Cardinal Cesarini when you address the Council. Let him see the Fisherman's Ring seal with his own eyes. It will not make you the Pope's legate, but it will prove you are not merely some foreign king meddling in Church affairs. You speak with Rome's encouragement, if not Rome's formal authority. That distinction matters, and the Cardinal will appreciate it.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Your logic is sound in principle, Your Majesty. Separate the theology from the theft. Grant communion in both kinds—which Scripture supports—while refusing to legitimize seizure of Church lands. The Utraquists here might accept such terms. They are moderates. They want reconciliation.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: But consider: the Utraquist delegation does not speak for Bohemia. They speak to Bohemia. Behind them stand the nobles who hold actual power—men who seized abbeys and monasteries and now draw rents from those properties. These nobles sent the Utraquists to Basel not because they desire theological peace, but because they want their theft sanctified by Church agreement. If the Utraquists return to Prague with terms that say 'you have your communion, but you must return the lands,' those nobles will reject the settlement entirely. The moderates will be discredited. The radicals—the Taborites, who believe all Church property is an abomination—will gain strength.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: And there is another complication. The Hussites justify the seizures theologically. They cite evangelical poverty—Christ and His apostles owned nothing, therefore the Church should own nothing, therefore seizing Church wealth is restoring proper Christian practice. When you say 'this is theft,' they say 'this is reform.' You are not merely arguing property law. You are arguing ecclesiology. What is the Church? What should it own? What is its proper relationship to worldly wealth?

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Can your approach work? Perhaps. If you can convince the Utraquists that evangelical poverty as a principle is compatible with respecting existing Church property—that reform means future simplicity, not retroactive seizure—you might thread the needle. But you would need to be extraordinarily persuasive. And even then, the Bohemian nobles must be compelled to return what they've taken. By whom? With what force? Emperor Sigismund has tried for fifteen years and failed.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott's expression shifted when you asked about Constance. He sat back, his voice taking on the tone of a teacher addressing a crucial misunderstanding.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Ah. Now we come to the heart of it. You ask if Constance established conciliar supremacy. The answer is: they claimed to, and that claim is precisely what this entire crisis is about.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: In 1415, with three rival popes each claiming legitimacy and Christendom torn apart, the Council of Constance issued a decree called Haec Sancta—'This Holy Council.' It declared, in language that could not be clearer, that the Council holds its authority directly from Christ. That everyone—everyone, including the Pope—is bound to obey the Council in matters of faith, ending schism, and Church reform. They used this decree to depose all three rival popes and elect Martin V, ending the Great Schism.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Then they issued Frequens, requiring that general councils meet regularly—first after five years, then seven, then every ten years perpetually. Pope Martin V accepted his election by the Council. He acknowledged Frequens and convened this Council of Basel according to its requirements.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: But here is where ambiguity becomes crisis. Martin V never explicitly endorsed Haec Sancta as permanent constitutional law. He accepted it as an emergency measure to end schism—not as a permanent subordination of papal authority to conciliar vote. When he died and Eugenius succeeded him, Eugenius took the same view: Constance solved a crisis, it did not rewrite the Church's constitution. The Pope remains supreme in his proper sphere.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: The Council fathers here invoke Haec Sancta as settled law. They say: Constance established our supremacy, the Pope must obey. Eugenius says: Constance was emergency measure, I am not bound by it. When he tried to dissolve this Council, they declared his dissolution invalid because Haec Sancta means they answer to no pope. When he summoned them to meet in Italy instead, they refused because Frequens says Basel was properly convened. They have even summoned him to appear before them—citing Constance's authority.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: This is not settled law, Your Majesty. This is open constitutional war. Both sides cite Constance, both interpret it differently, and neither will yield. If you argue for papal supremacy, you argue against Haec Sancta. If you argue for conciliar authority, you argue against the Pope who just blessed your crusade. There is no neutral ground. There is only choosing which interpretation of Constance you support—and living with the enemies that choice creates.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Listening first is wise. Wiser than most Western lords manage. The Greeks have been lectured to for eight months about Latin theological superiority. They have been told their Filioque rejection is error, their liturgical practices are deficient, their entire Eastern tradition is somehow lesser. They are proud men representing an ancient empire, and they have been treated as supplicants come to beg correction.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rose slowly from his chair, his joints protesting.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Hear their fears before you offer solutions. Learn what they actually need—not what we assume they need. They may surprise you. They may also test you. Bessarion is brilliant, a scholar who thinks in systems. Isidore is more practical, more political. Both are desperate enough to make deals but proud enough to reject condescension.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott moved toward the door, then paused.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: One more thing, Your Majesty. When you meet them, remember: they did not come to Basel to become Latin. They came hoping to remain Orthodox while receiving Latin swords. Every word you speak, they will weigh for signs of forced conversion, of theological imperialism, of another Fourth Crusade. If you can convince them you want to save Constantinople, not Latinize it, you may find them more receptive than you expect.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He bowed stiffly.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Shall I send word to Metropolitan Bessarion that you will receive them tomorrow? And would you prefer I attend, or would you meet them alone?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lets talk about the powers of the pope versus that of the council. There is no clear legal or even moral argument that is much better than the other in this matter. What will happen do you think if I say nothing about this and just let the council decide for itself? Can this council elect a new pope? The last council clearly did and could this council not do so again? What do you think will happen?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott had been reaching for the door handle. Your question stopped him mid-motion. He turned back, and something in his expression shifted—a sharpening of focus, as if you had finally asked the question he had been waiting for. He returned to his chair, lowering himself with renewed purpose.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Now you are thinking like a king who understands what is truly at stake.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: Can this Council elect a new pope? Legally, canonically, by precedent—yes. Constance did so. They deposed three rival popes and elected Martin. If Basel declares Eugenius deposed for contumacy—for refusing to submit to conciliar authority—and elects a new pope, they have Constance as their precedent. They would say they are not innovating. They are following established procedure.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: And Your Majesty, there are fathers here who want exactly that. The French delegation would celebrate. Cardinal Louis Aleman—who presides when Cesarini is absent—is a fierce conciliarist who believes Eugenius is a tyrant. Some Germans support deposition as the only way to force reform. Even some Italians who despise Eugenius personally would accept a new pope if it meant ending this paralysis.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: But consider what happens if they do. Eugenius will not accept deposition. He will remain in Rome, claiming he is the true pope. He has loyal cardinals—twenty-three signed your decree, yes? Those cardinals will not recognize Basel's pope. You will have two popes again. Not three as in the Great Schism, but two. And this time, one will be elected by a Council that claims supreme authority, the other will be the sitting pontiff who claims councils cannot depose him. Christendom will split. Every kingdom, every diocese, every monastery will have to choose: Basel's pope or Rome's pope. Another schism, Your Majesty. Perhaps worse than the last.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Abbott's hands gripped the chair arms.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: You ask what happens if you say nothing and let the Council decide. I will tell you what happens. Your silence will be interpreted. The French will say: 'Castile does not oppose us, therefore Castile accepts conciliar supremacy.' The papal loyalists will say: 'Castile received the Pope's blessing and now abandons him—they are cowards or traitors.' Cardinal Cesarini will wonder why the king who returned the crusade treasury and received perpetual grants from Eugenius suddenly has no opinion on whether Eugenius should remain pope.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stood again, too agitated now to remain seated.

exchanges.speaker: abbott_rodrigo_gonzalez
exchanges.text: And there is more. You carry that decree. Article Five declares an alliance between Rome and Castile founded in shared faith. If this Council deposes Eugenius and you have said nothing to defend him, what is that alliance worth? What does your word mean? You accepted his grants—the Military Orders in perpetuity, his support for Alfonso's Naples claim, his letters of blessing. You took everything he offered. And when his enemies moved to destroy him, you stood silent?

encounters.recap: Abbott Rodrigo González briefs Juan II on the complex political and theological dynamics at the Council of Basel. He explains the procedural complexity that makes decision-making slow, the factions involved (French conciliarists, divided Germans and Italians), and the key issues: papal supremacy versus conciliar authority, the Hussite property question, and Byzantine pleas for military aid. The Abbott warns that neutrality is impossible—remaining silent on papal authority would be interpreted as abandonment of Eugenius IV, potentially leading to another papal schism if the Council elects a rival pope.
