'Abandon your liturgy, then we will send ships.' 'Admit your theology is error, then we will consider aid.' Always conditions. Always demands that we cease to be Orthodox before we are worthy of Christian brotherhood. You show us proof of your authority. You commit exactly what we said we needed—not more, not less. You say you will write the order now. And you ask nothing of our faith. Nothing.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
exchanges.text: The logistics remain. Ships must be hired. Sailing seasons respected. A thousand knights must be provisioned for a long journey. But these are problems of execution, not problems of will. For the first time in eight months, we speak with a Western lord about how to help, not whether to help. Your Majesty, we must send word to Emperor John immediately. He must know that Castile offers real aid. This changes our entire negotiating position—not just here at Basel, but with Venice, with Genoa, with all who have watched Constantinople's slow death with indifference.

exchanges.speaker: isidore
exchanges.text: We have been... difficult. Suspicious. You understand why, yes? The Fourth Crusade is not ancient history to us. It is living memory. Our grandparents saw Latin soldiers sack our churches, melt our icons for gold, place a Latin patriarch in the Hagia Sophia. When Latins speak of 'helping' Constantinople, our blood runs cold. But you are different. We see this now. You speak of soldiers and florins, not theology and submission. You admit what you cannot yet deliver rather than promising everything and delivering nothing. You show us proof rather than asking for faith.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He glanced at Bessarion, who nodded.

exchanges.speaker: isidore
exchanges.text: We would discuss practical matters with you, Your Majesty. Shipping routes. Timing. How to coordinate your Military Orders with our garrison. How to ensure these sixty thousand florins reach Constantinople safely and are spent on walls rather than disappearing into corruption. We have much experience with... disappointment. We would plan carefully, with contingencies for what might go wrong.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
exchanges.text: And we would discuss the larger question—the crusade treasury you mentioned, the alliance with Aragon, the possibility of a true Western army that could threaten the Sultan in the field. Not as demands, but as hopes. As possibilities we might build toward together. Will you work with us on these details, Your Majesty? As partners?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Before we do, there is something important that we must address. When someone is drowning, you do not ask for reward before saving him. In your case, I seek not a reward per se, but we must discuss the new situation we create. Will my help create a permanent dependency on Castile? And even with every good will in the world, is Castile able to maintain this aid across generations? I can empty the treasury because it is mine to give, but even I cannot command my people to fight and die for a far and foreign land indefinitely? How strong is the Byzantine Empire and is just one strong push enough for help? Do not get me wrong, I do want to help. But I do have to ask the hard questions as well. Can Constantinople even be saved? And what do we have to do to make it so? To be concrete, must I create a new order and permanently station them in Constantinople? How big must they be and is the emperor prepared to allow this? Can Latin Christians settle in the city?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The two metropolitans' expressions shifted. Bessarion's scholarly composure returned, and Isidore's weathered face grew thoughtful. They exchanged a glance—this time one of respect for the question itself. Bessarion lowered himself back into his chair, his fingers steepled.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
exchanges.text: You ask the question that no Latin lord has asked us, Your Majesty. They promise aid without considering whether that aid solves the problem or merely delays it. You think as a strategist, not a sentimentalist. This is... good. Painful, but good. Can Constantinople be saved? If you mean 'can the city survive one Ottoman assault'—yes. With your thousand knights and sixty thousand florins, with walls repaired and professional soldiers on the ramparts, we could break a siege. The Sultan would bleed. He might withdraw, regroup, wait for better opportunity. But if you mean 'can the Byzantine Empire return to its former strength'—no. That empire is gone. We control Constantinople, a few Aegean islands, scraps of the Peloponnese. We are not an empire. We are a city-state pretending to imperial dignity.

exchanges.speaker: isidore
exchanges.text: Your Majesty asks the hard question, so we give the hard answer. Constantinople cannot survive indefinitely as it is. Our population shrinks. Our treasury empties. Our young men flee west seeking opportunity. Each generation, we grow weaker while the Ottomans grow stronger. One strong push? No. One strong push saves us for five years. Perhaps ten. Then the Sultan returns with more cannons, more troops, more determination.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
exchanges.text: For Constantinople to truly survive, it needs what you describe—permanent Western presence. Not charity, but partnership. Not emergency aid, but institutional commitment. Your question about a permanent military order... This touches on matters of sovereignty and faith that are delicate. The Emperor would accept Latin soldiers to man the walls—he has no choice. But a permanent military order? Knights who hold lands in Constantinople, who answer to their Order's Master rather than the Emperor, who maintain Latin rites in an Orthodox city? This is... complicated. We remember the Latin Empire. When the Fourth Crusade conquered us, they established a Latin Patriarch. Latin knights held Greek lands. Our people became second-class subjects in their own city. That occupation lasted fifty-seven years before we reclaimed Constantinople. The scars run deep.

exchanges.speaker: isidore
exchanges.text: You ask if Latin Christians can settle in the city. Some already do—Venetian and Genoese merchants have their quarters, their churches. We tolerate this. But a permanent military settlement? Thousands of Latin knights with their families, their priests, their Latin Masses? Our people would see this as slow conquest, not salvation. And yet—what choice do we have? Pride is a luxury the drowning cannot afford.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, you ask what must be done to save Constantinople permanently. I will tell you the truth that we barely speak even among ourselves: Constantinople survives only if the Ottoman threat is broken. Not contained. Not held at bay. Broken. The Sultan's power must be shattered so thoroughly that he cannot threaten us for generations. This means not defending walls, but offensive war. Driving the Turks from Europe entirely. Can Castile commit to such a war? Can any Western power? You speak of tens of thousands of troops, years of campaigning, fortunes spent. Emperor Sigismund tried and failed. Five crusades against the Hussites failed. The Ottomans are more formidable than either.

exchanges.speaker: isidore
exchanges.text: As for permanent dependency on Castile—Your Majesty, we are already dependent. On Venetian trade. On Genoese shipping. On whoever will sell us grain and weapons. Dependency on Castile would at least be dependency on someone who asks nothing of our faith.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I think for a long moment. My promise to repair the walls and my 1000 soldiers are given as gift and I ask nothing in return. It buys us time for you, for the Byzantine Empire, to make a choice. A choice about their future. The first choice is keep doing what we are doing right now. I support you and we delay the inevitable. We fight and die honourably in the defence of Christendom in the east. There is honour and simplicity in this, but the Empire would simply end. If we want to prevent this, far far more is needed. The second choice is migration. I offer every citizen of the empire refuge in my lands. An enormous operation, but together we can build and expand existing cities where your culture can bloom and blossom. not an empire of your own but living as respected brothers in my kingdom where we can honour God side by side. The third choice is the most ambitious and the most uncertain. We fight. We fight and we drive them from the continent completely. I am prepared to, but this will be extremely difficult. And if the empire does indeed wish this, it will be extremely dependant on Castilian aid and military security. It will require extraordinary effort on my part and on that of my kingdom. If we should decide to fight beyond the aid already given, I am only willing to give it if there is an actual chance of victory. I will regard this ask and cry for help for what it is: 'Help us please, for we cannot save ourselves.' I would have to think about what this would even look like, but I would require complete control and authority over the entire campaign. And the Byzantines themselves would be prepared as well to fight for their very survival as well. I hope you can see that from my perspective, these are the only best choices before us. And please understand that I do not want to extract things from you when your backs are against the wall. This is what I propose we do: I will instruct an expedition to be formed of 1000 of my best and most zealous order members. They will be led by officers trained in my academy, instructed how to counter Ottoman tactics. They carry 60.000 florins with Castilian experts and workers to help wall construction and repair. My officials will oversee that the funds are allocated to actual repairs. I can write this order tonight. Assembling this force will take some time, but I can set it in motion. Then, I will sail and visit your city myself to meet with your emperor himself and discuss the options before us. I hope you have had time to think and to make an informed choice. I can discuss what structure we would use should we go to war and other details about our cooperation when I meet with the emperor himself. There are many questions, i know. Will the help and cooperation reduce our independance? What about our culture? These matters will be discussed later when there is time and you have had time to think what you want. Only with the emperor can I definitively settle these matters. My aid gives us this time. What do you think?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The silence stretched long after you finished speaking. Bessarion had gone very still, his scholar's mind clearly working through the implications of each word. Isidore's weathered face showed something like pain—but also relief, the relief of a man finally hearing truth spoken plainly.

exchanges.speaker: isidore
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. In eight months, no one—no one—has spoken to us like this. They speak of 'saving Constantinople' as if it were simple. They promise aid as if a few thousand florins will restore an empire. They debate our theology as if correcting our Creed will make the Ottomans disappear. You speak truth. Harsh truth. 'You cannot save yourselves.' These words cut deep. But they are honest, and we have had enough of comfortable lies.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
exchanges.text: You offer us what no one else has—agency. Not 'accept our terms or perish,' but 'here is time to choose your fate.' The immediate aid without conditions gives us that time. This alone sets you apart from every Latin lord we have met. Let us engage with your framework honestly, as you have engaged with us. The first option—delay the inevitable, die honorably—this is what we have been doing. It is not a choice. It is surrender dressed in dignity. We reject it, though we may be forced to it regardless.

exchanges.speaker: isidore
exchanges.text: The second option—migration. Your Majesty, you offer something remarkable. Refuge for our people in your lands. But you must understand what you propose. Constantinople is not merely a city. It is the New Rome. The seat of Orthodox Christianity. The continuation of the Roman Empire itself. To abandon it... This is not moving to a new home. This is ending a thousand years of civilization. Our people, scattered in foreign lands, would cease to be Byzantines within a generation. The culture might survive in fragments. The empire would be gone.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
exchanges.text: And yet—if the choice is extinction or transformation, perhaps transformation is not surrender. Perhaps preserving our people, our faith, our learning in Castilian lands is better than skeletons in Constantinople's ruins. This requires much thought. The third option. War. Driving the Ottomans from Europe entirely. Your Majesty, you say you would require complete control and authority over the campaign. This is... enormous. You ask the Emperor to place Byzantine survival in your hands. To trust a foreign king with everything.

exchanges.speaker: isidore
exchanges.text: But consider our position. What authority do we actually have? Our army is five thousand men. Our treasury is empty. Our allies are absent. You offer real forces, real gold, real strategy. If we cannot save ourselves—and we cannot—then someone must save us. Better a king who asks nothing of our faith than lords who demand we cease to be Orthodox.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
exchanges.text: Concerns remain. 'Complete control'—does this mean you command our soldiers as well as your own? Does this mean you dictate our alliances, our diplomacy, our domestic policy? The Emperor will need clarity on these boundaries. And the war itself. You speak of driving Ottomans from Europe. Your Majesty, do you comprehend the scale? The Sultan commands perhaps eighty thousand troops. His janissaries are the finest infantry in the world. His artillery— What forces can you actually bring to bear? You mentioned Hungary, Poland. Emperor Sigismund has tried to unite these powers and failed. What makes you believe you will succeed where he has not?

exchanges.speaker: isidore
exchanges.text: And if you commit fully to this war and fail—what then? Castile is bankrupted, your Military Orders destroyed in Turkish lands, and Constantinople falls anyway. You risk everything.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
exchanges.text: Your proposal to visit Constantinople yourself—this is crucial. Only face to face with Emperor John can such matters be settled. He must see you, measure you, understand what manner of man offers his sword. We can carry your message, but we cannot make such decisions for him.

exchanges.speaker: isidore
exchanges.text: We will send word immediately. Emperor John must know that a Western king offers concrete aid without demanding theological submission. That you propose to come yourself, to discuss these options in person. This will mean much to him. Your Majesty, one question we must ask: your wife is with child. You must return to Toledo. When would you come to Constantinople? The journey is long. The sailing season has limits. Will you come this year? Next year? Time matters greatly to us.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
exchanges.text: We are grateful for your honesty. We engage with your framework seriously because you have treated us seriously. We have concerns—sovereignty, authority, the scale of commitment required. But these are concerns of partners discussing difficult realities, not supplicants being dictated to. This is... new for us. And welcome.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Thank you for taking me serious as well. I speak with sincerity and am grateful for you to do so as well. You mention your remaining concerns. And I understand that you cannot possibly make these choices for the empire yourself. Your questions are valid and will discuss them at length with your emperor before we make any choice. But I feel like I should be honest as well and not sugar coat the facts as well. If you do want me to help and also want to maintain sovereign control over your own soldiers? When your very existence is at stake? This is exactly why Christian armies lose and I hope you see how absurd this would look. Again, the choice is yours, but I will not participate in a war that has no chance of victory.

encounters.recap: Juan presents the Byzantine metropolitans with his papal decree and concrete military aid offer. He then outlines three stark choices for the Empire's future: honorable defeat, mass migration to Castile, or total war requiring complete Castilian command authority. The metropolitans respond constructively to his brutal honesty, agreeing to arrange a meeting with Emperor John in Constantinople to discuss these momentous decisions.

And welcome.

And I understand that you cannot possibly make these choices for the empire yourself. Your questions are valid and will discuss them at length with your emperor before we make any choice. But I feel like I should be honest as well and not sugar coat the facts as well. If you do want me to help and also want to maintain sovereign control over your own soldiers? When your very existence is at stake? This is exactly why Christian armies lose and I hope you see how absurd this would look. Again, the choice is yours, but I will not participate in a war that has no chance of victory.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And yes, I fully understand the terrifying scale of such an operation. But it is like you said; it is the only way to save the city and the empire. But that also means there is much to fight for. I have faced Islam in battle and I am not afraid to die, but I will need to find even more allies and rally many more support than I command myself. I will need to figure this out. But it all starts with the choice or your empire. A choice that also means consequences and the commitment you actually are prepared to make in order for us to win.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You ask as well what if we lose. Then I will probably be dead and my kingdom defeated. My wife and child will lose a father. Many more will suffer. But risking our lives is something we must be prepared to do if we want to win. If we are not prepared to die for victory, we have already lost. My soldiers will come as soon as possible. After my wife has given birth, I will come as soon as possible. I have my own fleet so I should be able to sail fast. I hope you understand I can not give you an exact timeline right now, all I give you is my word.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_bessarion
exchanges.text: You speak of unified command, and we resist instinctively. Pride. A thousand years of empire makes one proud. But you are right, Your Majesty. We come to you because we cannot save ourselves, then bristle when you say what salvation requires. This is... absurd. We see it. Whether the Emperor will see it... That remains to be discovered.

exchanges.speaker: isidore_of_kiev
exchanges.text: You say you are prepared to die. That your wife and child might lose you. That your kingdom might be bankrupted and defeated. Your Majesty, we have begged many lords for help these eight months. They speak of crusade as glory. They speak of driving back the Turk as if it were a tournament. You speak of death. Of loss. Of what failure actually costs.

exchanges.speaker: isidore_of_kiev
exchanges.text: This is why we trust you. Not because you promise victory—you do not. Not because you have certain plans—you admit you do not. We trust you because you understand what you offer to risk. A man who sees clearly the cost of failure and still commits—this is a man worth following into battle.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_bessarion
exchanges.text: Your word. You give us your word that you will come after your wife's delivery, as soon as possible. Your Majesty, in eight months we have received many promises. Yours is the first we believe. Not because we are naive, but because you have been honest about every uncertainty, every limitation, every risk. A man who speaks so plainly about what he cannot guarantee—his guarantees carry weight.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_bessarion
exchanges.text: We will write to Emperor John tonight. We will tell him everything. The immediate aid—one thousand knights, sixty thousand florins, no conditions. The three choices you have laid before us. Your willingness to come in person. Your requirement for unified command if we choose to fight. All of it, plainly stated.

exchanges.speaker: isidore_of_kiev
exchanges.text: We will advocate for you, Your Majesty. Not as supplicants grateful for scraps, but as metropolitans who have found a Western lord who treats us as partners rather than theological problems to be corrected. This means much.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_bessarion
exchanges.text: One thing we ask: when you send your thousand knights with the sixty thousand florins, send also a letter to the Emperor. In your own hand. Let him read your words directly. Let him see the man who offers such aid. We will carry your message, but your own voice will speak more powerfully than ours.

exchanges.speaker: isidore_of_kiev
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, you have given Constantinople something it has not had in many years: hope grounded in reality rather than desperate fantasy. Whether we choose to fight, to migrate, or to die with honor—at least now we have genuine choices before us. This is your gift, beyond the florins and the soldiers.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_bessarion
exchanges.text: We will not burden you further today. You have much to consider, much to plan. The order to Castile, the letter to the Emperor, your other negotiations here at Basel. We are at your disposal should you need us. And we will pray—Orthodox prayers, but prayers nonetheless—for Queen Isabel's safe delivery. May God grant her and the child health, and may He grant you wisdom for the path ahead.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Before you go, please tell me how the emperor and his family is doing? I dont really know about the emperor to be honest.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_bessarion
exchanges.text: Emperor John VIII Palaiologos. He is forty-one years old. A serious man. Thoughtful. Some say too thoughtful—he deliberates when others wish he would act. But in our situation, rashness would have doomed us years ago.

exchanges.speaker: isidore_of_kiev
exchanges.text: He inherited the throne from his father Manuel II in 1425. Manuel was a wise emperor who spent his reign desperately seeking Western aid—even traveled to England and France himself, decades ago. John continues his father's work. It is all he can do.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_bessarion
exchanges.text: His personal situation is... difficult. He has been married three times. His first wife, Anna of Moscow, died young—1417. His second wife, Sophia of Montferrat, left him after only a few years. She entered a convent. The marriage was... unhappy. His current wife is Maria of Trebizond. They married in 1427.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_bessarion
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, there is something you must understand. Emperor John has no children. No heir. This weighs heavily on him and on the empire. His brothers—Constantine, Theodore, Demetrios, Thomas—they wait in the wings. The succession is uncertain.

exchanges.speaker: isidore_of_kiev
exchanges.text: A childless emperor defending a dying empire. You see why hope has been scarce in Constantinople.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_bessarion
exchanges.text: John is educated, cultured. He speaks Latin adequately. He understands Western politics better than most of his predecessors. He is not hostile to the Latin Church—he is pragmatic. He knows that theological purity means nothing if Constantinople falls to the Turks.

exchanges.speaker: isidore_of_kiev
exchanges.text: But he is also proud. Proud of his lineage—he traces his authority back to Constantine the Great, to Augustus himself. He is the Roman Emperor, in his own mind. Asking him to surrender authority, even military authority, to a foreign king... It will not be easy for him to accept.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_bessarion
exchanges.text: He is also exhausted, Your Majesty. Eight years on the throne, each year worse than the last. Watching his empire shrink. Begging Western lords who lecture him about theology while his people starve. He sent us here to Basel with instructions to secure aid by any means possible—but 'any means' has limits even for desperate men.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_bessarion
exchanges.text: When you meet him—if you meet him—you will find a man who carries impossible weight. Who loves his people but cannot save them. Who rules an empire that exists more in memory than in reality. He will test you, Your Majesty. Not from hostility, but from the caution of a man who has been disappointed too many times.

exchanges.speaker: isidore_of_kiev
exchanges.text: But if you speak to him as you have spoken to us—with honesty, with concrete offers, without demanding he abandon his faith—he will listen. He is not a fool. He knows Constantinople's survival depends on Western aid. He simply needs to believe that aid comes without chains.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_bessarion
exchanges.text: One more thing. The Emperor's brother Constantine—he is the warrior of the family. Commands what military forces remain. If you propose war, Constantine will be your liaison with Byzantine forces. He is brave, capable, respected by the soldiers. If you win Constantine's trust, you win the army's trust.

encounters.recap: Juan II engages in deep strategic discussions with the Byzantine metropolitans about his three-choice framework for Constantinople. He insists on unified command if they choose war, acknowledging the mortal risks involved. The metropolitans are moved by his honesty about potential failure and death, finding him trustworthy precisely because he doesn't promise easy victory. They agree to advocate for him with Emperor John VIII, and Juan learns about the childless, exhausted emperor who faces impossible choices. The discussion concludes with plans for immediate aid and Juan's future personal journey to Constantinople after his wife gives birth.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The study falls into contemplative silence as the magnitude of what has transpired settles over all present. Metropolitan Bessarion remains seated, his scholarly face reflecting careful thought. Beside him, Isidore's gruffer expression has softened—not entirely, for the wounds of Western betrayals run deep—but something has shifted behind those weary eyes. Don Bernat de Centelles stands near the window, the Aragonese ambassador's expression unreadable. He has witnessed much in his years serving King Alfonso, but a Castilian king offering to bleed his kingdom dry for Constantinople's sake—this is something new.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The late morning sun slants through the leaded glass, casting diamond patterns across the maps and papers scattered on the heavy oak table. Outside, Basel continues its daily commerce, oblivious to the decisions being forged in this borrowed merchant's house.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
exchanges.text: Your Majesty has given us much to carry to our Emperor. Specific numbers. Immediate commitments. Honest assessment of risks and limitations. But before we write our letters—and you write yours—there are practical matters we must discuss. Questions the Emperor will ask that we should be prepared to answer.

exchanges.speaker: isidore
exchanges.text: The thousand knights you promise. How quickly can they reach Constantinople? By what route? What supplies will they need? The Ottomans control much of the land between here and there, and our seas are not safe.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Draft two letters. One to Alvaro de Luna, instructing him to assemble a force of 1000 soldiers drafted from the military orders. Allocate the war academy officers to this force. They will repair the walls of Constantinopel so masons and architects should also come, along with 60.000 florins from the treasury. This will allow us to repair the walls and man them as well. Have them shipped out as soon as possible. Another letter for the two Greeks here. A personal letter from me to the emperor, stating that I look forward to seeing him and will visit when my wife has delivered. Explain that I have discussed three opssible options for us to proceed and would like to discuss these with him in person. I hope the help offered is recieved in the spirit it was given and expect no reward or concession in return. What will you do now? Will you return to Constantinople now you have secured my aid? Or will you accompany me as I travel the European courts to ask for aid?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando, who has been standing quietly near the door throughout the meeting, steps forward at his King's summons. His Franciscan robes rustle softly as he moves to the writing desk, his weathered face showing the careful attention of a man who has witnessed something significant unfold.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: At once, Your Majesty. I will draft both letters for your review and seal. The instructions to Don Álvaro will be precise—Military Order knights, academy officers, masons, architects, and the treasury allocation. Shall I specify a particular port of departure, or leave that to the Constable's judgment?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The two Metropolitans exchange a glance—one of those silent communications between men who have worked together through long months of disappointment. Bessarion's scholarly face shows careful consideration; Isidore's gruffer expression carries something harder to read.

exchanges.speaker: isidore
exchanges.text: Your Majesty does us great honor with such an offer. To have Byzantine voices beside you when you approach other courts... But we cannot. We are the Emperor's representatives, not free agents. What you have committed today—the thousand knights, the sixty thousand florins, the concrete timeline—this news must reach Constantinople with all possible speed. John must know that hope exists. Real hope. Not the empty promises we have heard for years.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
exchanges.text: My brother speaks truth. We have been away eight months already. Every week we delay is another week the Emperor waits in uncertainty. Another week Sultan Murad uses to strengthen his position. But there is another consideration, Your Majesty. When you approach other courts—France, England, the German princes—you will speak as one who has already committed his own kingdom's resources. You do not ask others to take risks you have not taken yourself. That testimony speaks louder than our presence ever could.

exchanges.speaker: isidore
exchanges.text: We will carry your letter to John. We will tell him everything—the three options, your honesty about risks, your refusal to demand theological submission. We will tell him that a Latin king wept when we described our children's fear, and then stood and named specific numbers. That story, told by us who witnessed it, will mean more than any formal embassy.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
exchanges.text: And when you come to Constantinople yourself—after your wife is safely delivered—we will be there to receive you. Not as supplicants greeting a benefactor, but as partners who have already begun the work together.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Dont worry about me, I will find your city. But I would like it if you wait for just a few days so you can witness my adress to the council. Your testimony for aid offered should we public knowledge. Will you stay for my adress at least?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The two metropolitans exchange another of their silent looks. Isidore's jaw tightens—the impatience of a man who has already spent eight months waiting while his people suffer is visible in every line of his weathered face. But Bessarion's scholarly mind is clearly working through the implications.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
exchanges.text: A few days. Your Majesty intends to address the full Council? The general congregation?

exchanges.speaker: isidore
exchanges.text: Eight months we have begged these Latin prelates for aid. Eight months of theological debates while our walls crumble. And now a king who has actually fought Saracens will stand before them and say he has already committed his kingdom's blood and gold... Yes. This we will witness. This we will carry back to John—not just your private promise, but your public declaration before the assembled fathers of the Western Church.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
exchanges.text: And if other princes hear that Castile has committed a thousand knights and sixty thousand florins—if they see that one kingdom has already moved from words to deeds—perhaps shame will accomplish what eight months of our pleading could not. When do you intend to speak, Your Majesty? We can delay our departure by days, not weeks. Every day matters.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will ask for permission to speak soon, I will let you know and get you invited. For now i thank you for your time. Untill we meet again. What day is it and when do we have to leave for Toledo to be in time to honour my promise to Isabel?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The two metropolitans rise, and for the first time since they entered the room, something other than bitter exhaustion shows in their bearing. Bessarion bows with the formal grace of Byzantine court protocol, while Isidore's bow is shorter, more martial—but no less sincere.

exchanges.speaker: bessarion
exchanges.text: Until we meet again, Your Majesty. We will await word of your address. And we will pray—to the same God, whatever our theological disputes—that what has begun in this room today bears fruit.

exchanges.speaker: isidore
exchanges.text: You asked earlier if we even wanted Western help. We have wanted it for decades. We had simply stopped believing it would come without chains attached. Perhaps we were wrong.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Today is May twenty-ninth, Your Majesty. You promised Queen Isabel you would return before her delivery, which the physicians expect in late July or early August—let us say the middle of August to be safe, though first children often come early. The journey from Basel to Toledo... through Burgundy, then France, over the Pyrenees, across Castile. Three weeks at minimum if we ride hard with good weather and fresh horses at each stage. Four weeks if we encounter difficulties—and summer storms in the mountains are not uncommon. If we wish to arrive in Toledo by mid-July—giving you time with the Queen before the birth—we must depart Basel no later than the third week of June. That gives you perhaps three weeks here, Your Majesty. Emperor Sigismund is crowned in Rome in two days—May thirty-first. He will likely reach Basel sometime in late June, perhaps early July. You may have only narrow window to meet him before you must depart, if any window at all.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lets summon the papal legate to ask permission to adress the council in a few days hopefully. I also want to speak with the hussites, the french, german and italian delegations as well before the council.

encounters.recap: Juan orders military aid to Constantinople through letters to Álvaro de Luna (1000 knights, officers, masons, 60,000 florins) and Emperor John VIII. The Greek metropolitans decline to accompany Juan on his diplomatic tour but agree to witness his planned Council address. Timeline pressure emerges: Juan must depart Basel by late June to return to Isabel before her delivery, leaving only three weeks for diplomatic work including potential meeting with Emperor Sigismund.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Today is May twenty-ninth, Your Majesty. You promised Queen Isabel you would return before her delivery, which the physicians expect in late July or early August—let us say the middle of August to be safe, though first children often come early. The journey from Basel to Toledo... through Burgundy, then France, over the Pyrenees, across Castile. Three weeks at minimum if we ride hard with good weather and fresh horses at each stage. Four weeks if we encounter difficulties—and summer storms in the mountains are not uncommon. If we wish to arrive in Toledo by mid-July—giving you time with the Queen before the birth—we must depart Basel no later than the third week of June. That gives you perhaps three weeks here, Your Majesty. Emperor Sigismund is crowned in Rome in two days—May thirty-first. He will likely reach Basel sometime in late June, perhaps early July. You may have only narrow window to meet him before you must depart, if any window at all.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let us summon the papal legate to ask permission to address the council in a few days hopefully. I also want to speak with the Hussites, the French, German and Italian delegations as well before the council.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty... I must counsel caution. What you propose—meeting with all these delegations, securing permission to address the full Council, all within days—this is not how Basel functions. I have been here eight months, Your Majesty. Eight months watching how this Council operates. A single reform decree on clerical pluralism—something everyone agrees needs reform—took four months from proposal to passage. Four months of deputation meetings, procedural arguments, jurisdictional disputes. To address the general congregation, you must first petition the papal legate—yes, Cardinal Cesarini. But he cannot simply grant permission. The four deputations must agree. Each deputation must vote internally. The French will ask why a king with papal backing should address their Council. The radicals will suspect you've come to undermine their authority. And the Hussites, Your Majesty? You wish to speak with men who have fought off five papal crusades? You have just completed a crusade with papal blessing. You carry relics given by a Pope. Why should they trust you? What assurance do they have that you won't denounce them as heretics the moment you leave their presence? I do not say these meetings are impossible. But 'a few days'? Your Majesty, securing an audience with the Hussite delegation alone could take a week of negotiations. They are careful men, suspicious of Latin princes. And rightly so.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: That is fine. We just take it step by step. If I can't address the council, I will just make my declaration personally outside the council structure and leave it to my delegation to participate in the council. Either way, I need you by my side from now on. I have today and two more days left on my confession work so we will stay here for those days at least. Can we at least invite the papal legate or meet him? What do you think?

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I must speak plainly, as your confessor and as one who cares for your soul. This 'declaration outside the Council structure'—I must counsel strongly against it. You have been here one day. One day. And already you speak of making public pronouncements that bypass the assembled fathers of Christendom? How will this appear? A king with papal backing, fresh from crusade, arrives in Basel and immediately circumvents the Council's authority to make his own declarations? The radical conciliarists will see exactly what they fear—a papal agent undermining their legitimacy. Cardinal Aleman's faction will use your words as proof that Rome sends agents to subvert them. And Cardinal Cesarini... Your Majesty, I saw what you saw this morning. I heard his weeping in that chapel. I spoke with him three times over eight months. The man carries the weight of preventing schism on his shoulders, and that weight is crushing him. To request an audience now, when he is in such fragile state, when you have only just arrived and already speak of declarations and meetings with every faction... I fear this appears not as humble seeking of guidance, but as a king who wishes to reshape the Council to his purposes. And perhaps—forgive me, Your Majesty—perhaps I fear what I see in your eagerness. You came here speaking of spiritual uncertainty, of dark nights of the soul. Yet within hours you plan meetings with Hussites, French, Germans, Italians, personal declarations... Is this the measured wisdom of a king seeking God's path? Or is it the impatience of a man who believes his vision must be imposed quickly before doubt can take root? I will remain by your side. I will help with your confession work. But I cannot in good conscience help arrange meetings or declarations that may do more harm than good—to this Council, to your mission, and perhaps to your soul.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What course of action do you propose as I want to conduct diplomacy with these factions? I'm eager to learn.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty asks for guidance. Here is what I propose. First—and this is most important—you must complete your confession work. Three days of prayer, reflection, examination of conscience. Not as obligation to be endured while planning diplomacy, but as genuine spiritual foundation. Every morning at the cathedral. Every evening in reflection. You came here speaking of dark nights and lost paths. Find them first. Everything else flows from that. Second, you must understand that you are not the actor here. Your delegation—myself, Bishop Alfonso de Cartagena, the others—we have been here eight months. We have built relationships. We understand the currents. We know who trusts whom, who fears what. If diplomacy is to be conducted, let us conduct it in your name. You are the King of Castile. Kings do not petition for meetings. Kings do not chase down delegations. Your representatives do this. Third, listen before speaking. Attend the general congregation as observer. Sit quietly. Watch the deputations debate. See how the French argue, how the Germans respond, how the Italians maneuver. Learn the rhythm of this place before you try to change its tune. A week of observation would teach you more than a hundred meetings. Fourth—and hear me well—abandon this notion of personal declarations. If you have commitments to announce, let your delegation present them formally through proper Council channels. 'King Juan II of Castile has committed one thousand knights to Constantinople's defense.' Let them say it. In proper session. Through proper procedure. This honors the Council's authority while still making your position known. Finally, regarding Cesarini and the other leaders—if meetings are to happen, let them come to you. You are a king who has completed the Reconquista. You do not need to seek audiences. When word spreads of what you told the Byzantines today—and it will spread—others will seek you out. Let them come. Receive them graciously. Listen to their concerns. Ask questions. Make no promises, no declarations, no grand pronouncements. This is the course of humility, Your Majesty. This is how a wise king conducts diplomacy—through patience, through representatives, through listening. Not through eagerness and personal intervention. Does this counsel sit well with you? Or does it feel too slow, too cautious for what your heart desires?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Ha! Of course it feels too slow! I think I start to understand why the church is such a beast. I don't have time for this. But I respect your council and will not force the matter. The Greek matter was urgent and I have now addressed it. I will let my delegation do their work. What would be the most appropriate way to meet with the papal legate?

roll.outcome: Cautious Reservation - Agrees to stay but expresses serious concern about personal declaration plan; advises against anything that bypasses Council; suggests meeting Cesarini may be premature given his obvious strain

encounters.recap: Fray Hernando warns Juan about the complex timeline constraints of returning to Castile before Isabel's delivery and the slow pace of Basel's diplomatic procedures. When Juan proposes ambitious meeting plans, Hernando strongly counsels against bypassing Council structures and offers detailed guidance on proper diplomatic conduct. Juan reluctantly accepts the slower approach, acknowledging the church's bureaucratic nature while asking for appropriate ways to meet Cardinal Cesarini.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Fourth—and hear me well—abandon this notion of personal declarations. If you have commitments to announce, let your delegation present them formally through proper Council channels. 'King Juan II of Castile has committed one thousand knights to Constantinople's defense.' Let them say it. In proper session. Through proper procedure. This honors the Council's authority while still making your position known.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Finally, regarding Cesarini and the other leaders—if meetings are to happen, let them come to you. You are a king who has completed the Reconquista. You do not need to seek audiences. When word spreads of what you told the Byzantines today—and it will spread—others will seek you out. Let them come. Receive them graciously. Listen to their concerns. Ask questions. Make no promises, no declarations, no grand pronouncements.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: This is the course of humility, Your Majesty. This is how a wise king conducts diplomacy—through patience, through representatives, through listening. Not through eagerness and personal intervention. Does this counsel sit well with you? Or does it feel too slow, too cautious for what your heart desires?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Ha! Of course it feels too slow! I think I start to understand why the church is such a beast. I dont have time for this. But I respect your council and will not force the matter. The Greek matter was urgent and I have now adressed it. I will let my delegation to do their work. What would be the most appropriate way to meet with the papal legate?

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Yes, Your Majesty. The Church is indeed a beast—and one that moves at its own pace regardless of the urgency others feel. Many a king has learned this lesson with frustration. The papal legate... Cardinal Cesarini. Yes, this meeting would be appropriate. Indeed, it would be expected. You are a king with papal blessing, carrying relics given by Pope Martin himself. That Cesarini should receive you is proper protocol, not presumption.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Here is what I propose. I will go to the Cardinal's residence this afternoon—not as your envoy demanding audience, but as a fellow cleric. I will tell him simply: King Juan II of Castile has arrived in Basel. His Majesty has completed his confession work under my guidance and wishes to pay his respects to the papal legate before departing the city. He seeks no favor, makes no demands. He merely wishes to present himself properly to the Pope's representative, as any faithful Catholic king should.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Can you do this, Your Majesty? Can you meet with Cardinal Cesarini simply to pay respects, to listen, to offer no solutions and make no declarations? Can you sit with a man in pain and not try to fix everything?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I appreciate your council Fray. But now let me be honest as well. The council looks trapped to me. A beast that is wounded and cannot free itself from the trap it has fallen into. When I try to free it, it will growl and resist as is it's nature. But I must ignore it and act against it's instinct if I want to eventually help it. The best course of action for the pope to stay relevant and prevent scism is for him to enact the laws already passed by the council. I will ask and test if a system where a law approved by the four chambers cannot be vetoed by the pope would be something that would work.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan shows him the papal decree and his mention in the council.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Not five minutes ago, you said—and I quote your words precisely—'I respect your counsel and will not force the matter.' You acknowledged that your eagerness was perhaps unwise. And now? Now you compare the Church to a wounded beast too stupid to know what is good for it. A beast that must be forced against its instincts by one who knows better—you. You tell me the best course of action for the Pope. You propose specific reform mechanisms. You cite this decree not to ask what it means, but to justify what you already wished to do before I offered any counsel at all.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: This document gives you a role, yes. A role to support the Pope's vision, to advocate for papal authority, to help the Holy Father as his faithful servant. It does not appoint you architect of a new constitutional order for the Church. The trapped beast that 'cannot free itself'—Your Majesty, the men of this Council are not bishops, cardinals, scholars who have spent their entire lives studying these questions. You, after one day in Basel, believe you see what they cannot?

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: This is pride, Your Majesty. Dangerous pride. The same pride that makes a man believe his vision is God's vision, that his certainty is divine guidance. I will not help you arrange meetings or present proposals until you have spent real time in prayer and reflection—not as formality, but as genuine examination. Ask yourself: Am I seeking to serve God, or am I seeking to be the one who solved the Church's crisis?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Fray, I always want to be honest with you. And to speak my mind, for it will allow me to search my soul and reflect on it together with you. Please do not judge me for speaking my mind, for I would not share these things with others, nor do I tell you what you want to hear. Would you not rather have me be honest and bare my soul to you? I think I understand what you say, I will complete the rest of the day in prayer and contemplation. I know that my own vision is not God's vision and that I do not experience divine guidance. Hopefully divine inspiration. But I will reflect on this as well.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan walks up to Fray Hernando and takes his hand.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will always be honest with you Fray, and I value your council. I do not always agree with it to be honest, but I do work on and reflect on it. I have prayed this morning and will spend the rest of the day in reflection. This evening, I would like to speak with you again and prepare myself for tomorrow and the reflection of the second day.

encounters.recap: Fray Hernando counsels Juan toward patience and diplomatic restraint, but when Juan immediately argues for his reform agenda citing papal authorization, the friar delivers a sharp rebuke about pride and spiritual danger. Juan accepts the need for prayer and reflection, promising a day of contemplation before proceeding.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I think I understand what you say, I will complete the rest of the day in prayer and contemplation. You ask if I can spend a day without planning and scheming. I can keep to myself for a day, sure. But my mind goes towards what you mean by scheming all the time. I cannot stop thinking about the situation to be honest. But I can reflect on myself and I will, you have my word. I know that my own vision is not God's vision and that I do not experience divine guidance. Hopefully divine inspiration. But I will reflect on this as well. And I do feel a responsibility to help the council in the way I feel it should be helped. You council humility, I will reflect on this. I will always be honest with you Fray, and I value your council. I do not always agree with it to be honest, but I do work on and reflect on it. I have prayed this morning and will spend the rest of the day in reflection. This evening, I would like to speak with you again and prepare myself for tomorrow and the reflection of the second day.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty speaks of honesty, and I do value this. Truly. You are right that many kings would simply tell their confessors what they wish to hear, then proceed as they please. That you do not—that you bare your thoughts even when you know I will challenge them—this is to your credit.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He does not withdraw his hand, but his grip firms slightly as he meets Juan's eyes.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: But hear what you have just said, Your Majesty. In one breath: 'I know my own vision is not God's vision.' In the next: 'I feel a responsibility to help the council in the way I feel it should be helped.' Do you see? You speak the words of humility, then immediately assert your own judgment. You acknowledge you may be wrong, then proceed as though you are right.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The friar gently releases Juan's hand and steps back.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: And this—'I do not always agree with your counsel, but I reflect on it'—Your Majesty, a confessor's role is not to offer suggestions you may agree or disagree with as it pleases you. When I speak to your soul's health, I speak as one who sees dangers you may not. A physician does not offer his patient options. He prescribes what will heal.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moves toward the door, then pauses.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: But yes. Spend this day in reflection. Pray. Examine not your plans for the Council, but your heart. Ask yourself why you must help, why you must act, why patience feels so unbearable. These are the questions that matter.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His expression softens just slightly.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: I will return this evening. We will speak. And Your Majesty—thank you for your honesty. It is indeed better than falsehood. But honesty about one's flaws is only the first step. The harder step is allowing those flaws to be corrected. Until this evening, Your Majesty. May God grant you clarity in your reflection.

encounters.recap: Fray Hernando challenges Juan's spiritual contradictions, pointing out how the king speaks of humility while asserting his own judgment. The friar emphasizes that honesty about flaws is only the first step—allowing those flaws to be corrected is harder. Their relationship deepens through this honest but difficult confrontation.

exchanges.speaker: heinrich_moller
exchanges.text: Ha! At least you are honest man. This is something. Most men who want to fix everyone's saddle, they do not admit it. They say, 'No, no, I only want to help. They need my help. They just do not see it yet.' You? You say, 'Yes, I am that man.' This is good. This is beginning of wisdom.

exchanges.speaker: heinrich_moller
exchanges.text: But let me tell you something, my Spanish friend. I have been making saddles forty years. Forty years. And you know what I have learned? The best saddlers—the ones people come to from miles away—they are not the ones with cleverest ideas. They are the ones who listen best.

exchanges.speaker: heinrich_moller
exchanges.text: When young apprentice comes to me, first thing he wants to do is show me his ideas. 'Master, I have thought of new way to stitch!' 'Master, what if we put buckle here instead?' Always the ideas. I tell him: sit. Watch. Listen. Make the simple saddles first. Learn why things are done the way they are done. Then maybe—maybe—you earn the right to suggest changes.

exchanges.speaker: heinrich_moller
exchanges.text: Those men in the Council? They have been making saddles long time. Longer than you, I think. Maybe their saddle does not fit so well. Maybe it needs fixing. But if you walk in and say, 'I see your problem, here is my solution'—what do they hear? They hear young apprentice who thinks he knows better than master craftsman.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I like the saddle maker comparison good master. What I did in real life does not matter really to what we are discussing. But consider this. I may be young, but maybe I am an experienced saddle maker already. And I have the written testimony to prove it, another master has testified to my ability. Would you see me for my ability or still the young apprentice with ambitious and unproven ideas?

exchanges.speaker: heinrich_moller
exchanges.text: Written testimony. Another master says you are good. My friend, I have seen many written testimonies in my time. Lords come to me with letters saying their previous saddler was master of his craft. Then I see the saddle he made, and the horse's back is bleeding.

exchanges.speaker: heinrich_moller
exchanges.text: You ask if I would see your ability or see young apprentice? I tell you what I would see. I would see man who talks about his written testimony instead of showing me his work. I would see man who asks, 'Would you respect my credentials?' instead of asking, 'May I watch how you work?'

exchanges.speaker: heinrich_moller
exchanges.text: Maybe you are experienced. Maybe you have made good saddles. I do not know—I have not seen them. But I tell you this: true master does not need to argue he is master. He shows his work. He lets work speak.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: An honest choice...forcing my way on fools who do not want it or walking away and make my own saddles. I think I have been so terrified of walking away that forcing my way on fools seemed like the only option. But I do think I have been trying too hard to change something that does not want to be changed. I wanted to make it easy for myself by taking control. But I think I now understand that letting go is actually a lot harder.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The saddler says nothing. He returns to his stitching, the rhythmic pull of needle through leather the only sound between them. He is a man comfortable with silence, with letting thoughts settle like sediment in still water.

exchanges.speaker: heinrich_moller
exchanges.text: Letting go. Yes. Very hard thing. Hardest thing, maybe, for a man who sees problems and knows he can fix them. To stand back and say, 'This is not mine to fix.' To trust that maybe the problem works itself out. Or maybe it does not, and that is sad, but still not yours.

exchanges.speaker: heinrich_moller
exchanges.text: But here is the secret, my friend. Sometimes when you let go—when you stop forcing—things come to you. You make your own good saddles in your own workshop, people hear about it. They come to you. They say, 'I have heard of your work. Will you look at my saddle?' And then—then—you can help. Because they asked.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan returns from the bread stall, the warm loaf fragrant in his hands. He breaks it carefully—the crust crackling, the soft interior steaming slightly in the afternoon air. Without ceremony, he sets one half on the bench beside the saddler and settles back on the fountain's edge with his own portion.

exchanges.speaker: heinrich_moller
exchanges.text: Danke. Thank you.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: They eat in silence. The bread is simple but good—honest food made by someone who knows their craft. The fountain burbles. The saddler's hands, scarred and strong, break off pieces with the same careful precision he brings to his stitching.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: My name is Juan by the way. Thank you for the talk, I appreciate it greatly. Have a nice day sir and go with God.

exchanges.speaker: heinrich_moller
exchanges.text: Juan. Good Spanish name. Strong. I am Heinrich. Heinrich Möller. Forty years making saddles in this square.

exchanges.speaker: heinrich_moller
exchanges.text: You go with God also, Juan. You have good head, I think. But more important—you have ears that listen. This is rare thing. Many men with good heads, they forget to listen. You? You listened to old saddler ramble about leather and stitching. You took his words seriously.

exchanges.speaker: heinrich_moller
exchanges.text: Remember what I said about letting go. Is hard. Very hard. But is also freedom. You stop carrying weight of fixing everything, you find your back does not hurt so much, yes?

exchanges.speaker: heinrich_moller
exchanges.text: And remember other thing too—the good saddler, he makes his own saddles well first. Everything else comes from that. You want to help the world? Make your own work excellent. People notice excellent work. They come to you.

exchanges.speaker: heinrich_moller
exchanges.text: Now go. Think your thoughts. Pray your prayers. And maybe—maybe—you find that cathedral does not need you to save it today. Maybe today, it is enough to save yourself. Go with God, Juan of Spain. May He grant you wisdom to know which saddles are yours to fix, and peace to let go of the ones that are not.

roll.outcome: Thoughtful Parting - Moved by Juan's humility; shares something personal about his own life; wishes him well with real feeling; remembers this stranger

encounters.recap: Juan encounters Heinrich Möller, an elderly saddler in Cathedral Square, who offers profound wisdom about humility and knowing when to let go of trying to fix others. Through metaphors of saddle-making, Heinrich teaches Juan that true masters listen first, earn respect through their work rather than credentials, and understand that sometimes the hardest choice is walking away from problems that don't want to be solved. Juan shares bread with the craftsman in a moment of genuine connection before continuing his contemplation.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan climbs the stone steps to Basel Cathedral's great doors. The red sandstone edifice looms above him, its twin towers reaching toward heaven. He has seen many cathedrals—Toledo, Burgos, even Rome's great churches—but there is something different about this one. It feels less like a house of worship and more like a fortress under siege.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He pushes through the heavy doors and steps inside. The nave stretches before him, vast and shadowed despite the afternoon light filtering through high windows. But this is not the quiet sanctuary he expected. The cathedral has been transformed into something else entirely—a parliament chamber, a debating hall, a battlefield of words.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Wooden benches have been arranged in rows facing a raised platform at the crossing. Hundreds of men in ecclesiastical robes fill these benches—black Benedictine habits, brown Franciscan robes, white Dominican cloaks, the purple of bishops, the red of cardinals. The air is thick with the smell of incense, candle wax, old stone, and too many bodies in an enclosed space.

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: ...and therefore the deputation of Doctors proposes that the matter of clerical concubinage be remanded to committee for further study of canonical precedents before any decree is issued...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A murmur ripples through the assembly. Someone calls out in French-accented Latin: 'Further study? We have studied this matter for three months already! The faithful cry out for reform while we debate precedents!' Another voice, German: 'Procedure must be followed. Without proper canonical foundation, any decree will be challenged.' Italian: 'The Holy Father himself has spoken on this matter. Why do we not simply implement his guidance?' The French voice again, sharper: 'Because this Council does not take orders from Rome! We are not the Pope's servants—we are Christ's!'

exchanges.speaker: cardinal_cesarini
exchanges.text: Brothers, please. We must maintain decorum. The question before us is procedural, not theological...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan finds a place in the shadows near the back, leaning against a stone pillar where he can observe without being noticed. The debate continues. It is, he realizes, exactly what Abbot Rodrigo described. Faction against faction. French radicals pushing for conciliar supremacy. German moderates seeking compromise. Italian loyalists defending papal prerogative. And threading through it all, the weary figure of Cesarini trying to hold the center together.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He watches for nearly an hour. In that time, no decision is reached. The matter is indeed remanded to committee. Another matter is raised—something about benefices—and the same dance begins again. As the afternoon wanes, the session begins to break up. Small clusters of clerics form, continuing debates in lower voices. Juan remains in his shadowed corner, watching.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Near him, two men in bishop's purple pass by, speaking in low but heated Italian. 'Cesarini cannot hold this together much longer. Did you see his face? The man is exhausted.' 'Exhausted or not, he is our only hope. If Aleman's faction gains control...' 'Then we have a Council that deposes Eugenius and elects their own Pope. And we have schism again.' 'Perhaps schism is better than this paralysis.' 'You do not mean that.' A pause. 'No. No, I do not. But something must break, one way or another.'

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The cathedral slowly empties as delegates depart for evening meals and private meetings. The great space grows quieter, though never entirely silent—clerics still kneel in various chapels, their prayers murmuring like distant water. Juan remains, watching the last light filter through the windows, casting colored shadows across the stone floor.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I realize that the question 'What if I am wrong?', does not refer to my reforms or measures, but about me wanting to force change upon the church itself. I must learn to let it go and accept that the church may tear itself apart and there is nothing I can do about this. That maybe the best thing to do is to just do good, or to make a good saddle and trust that others see this as well.

encounters.recap: Juan observes a Council session in Basel Cathedral, witnessing the factional debates and procedural paralysis that plague the assembly. The experience leads him to a crucial realization about letting go of his desire to force change upon the Church, instead embracing the saddlemaker's wisdom of focusing on doing good work and trusting others to recognize it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The chapel Juan finds is small and empty—a side altar dedicated to Saint Barbara, tucked away from the main nave. A single candle flickers before the saint's image, casting dancing shadows on the stone walls. The noise of the departing Council delegates fades to nothing here. He kneels on the cold stone. No cushion. The discomfort feels right somehow. What if I am wrong? The question he brought to Basel, the weight on his soul. But he has been asking it about the wrong things. He thought he was asking: What if my reforms are wrong? What if my plans fail? No. The deeper question: What if my certainty that I must act is itself the wrong? The saddler's words echo: The arrogance is not in wanting to help. The arrogance is in thinking you must help whether they want it or not. And: Letting go. Very hard thing. Juan's hands clasp tighter on the prayer rail. He has completed the Reconquista. He has returned relics to Rome. He has committed a thousand knights to Constantinople. And still—still—he arrives in Basel for one day and believes he must reshape the Church's constitution. Why? Because he cannot bear the thought of it tearing itself apart while he watches. Because he sees the problem clearly and cannot accept that he might not be the solution. Because letting go feels like failure, like abandoning his duty, like cowardice. But what if letting go is the hardest courage of all? The candle flickers. Saint Barbara gazes down with painted serenity. She who was martyred by her own father rather than renounce her faith. She did not try to fix the world. She simply held to what was true and let God handle the rest. Make your own saddles well first. Everything else comes from that. Juan prays. Not the formal prayers of a king, not the grand petitions of a crusader. Simple, anguished words offered into the darkness of a side chapel.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The sun has set by the time Juan returns to his quarters. The simple meal sits on the table—bread, cheese, cold meat, a cup of wine. Plain fare. He eats slowly, tasting little, his mind still in that small chapel. When Fray Hernando enters, the friar's sharp eyes immediately take in Juan's demeanor. Something has changed since this afternoon. The eager energy, the impatience to act—they are muted. In their place sits something quieter. Perhaps genuine reflection. Perhaps exhaustion. Perhaps both. Hernando settles into a chair across from Juan, his Franciscan robes rustling. He does not speak immediately, waiting instead to let the King set the tone. His weathered face shows caution, but also something like hope—the hope of a confessor who has prayed for his charge's soul and wonders if those prayers might be answered. The candles flicker between them. Outside, Basel settles into evening quiet.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Forgive me father, for I have sinned. I have mistaken the great victories you have granted me for blessing, the confidence you have given me for conviction in my own vision. This has led me to the arrogance to reform your church. I pray my intentions are pure, for I care greatly for your church, but I see now that it is not up to me to change this. I am your servant o Lord, and it is time for me to again understand this. I will serve you, not as a general or king, but as your humble, sinful servant. "What if I am wrong?", was the question you placed on me. And fortunately you place wise men on my path who have made me see that it is wrong for me to try and change the church. Even if all what I believe is right and all my reforms would help, then I would still be wrong to suggest it. I have been looking at the problem all wrong. I have been asking myself what is wrong with my actions while I should have been asking if it is right for me to act in the first place. And I now see the grace in letting that go. Even if it pains me greatly, this is merely the pain and hardship that comes with walking on the right path. And even in all of my sins father, I ask for you to be with me. And to help me. Grant your faithful servant Fray Hernando the patience to continue to help me. I do not deserve your mercy or your attention and I feel...small when I ask such things from you. Unworthy, yes. I am not perfect and never will be. I pray you grant this servant the chance to search his soul today and tomorrow on the second day of reflection. I ask this in Jezus name.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Your Majesty speaks beautiful words. Humble words. Words of repentance and self-knowledge. Words any confessor would be glad to hear. This morning, you spoke humble words also. You said you respected my counsel. You said you would not force the matter. You said you would complete your confession work. And then, within moments—moments, Your Majesty—you were arguing for why your plans should proceed. You showed me the papal decree. You explained why you must reform the Church. You had the language of humility, but the actions of a man who had already decided. Now you come to me with a confession of arrogance, of letting go, of understanding that it is not your place to change the Church. You speak of being God's humble servant. And I want to believe you, Your Majesty. I have prayed for this moment. I have begged God to open your eyes to the spiritual dangers I see. But I must ask: what has changed? This afternoon you were determined. Now you are contrite. This morning you agreed with my counsel, then immediately argued against it. How do I know this is not the same pattern? How do I know that tomorrow morning, when some messenger arrives or some opportunity presents itself, you will not again find reasons why your vision must proceed? You speak of letting go, of accepting that the Church may tear itself apart. These are profound realizations. But Your Majesty, I have been your confessor long enough to know that profound realizations in the evening can become forgotten wisdom by morning. The spirit is willing, but the flesh is weak. Tell me plainly, Your Majesty. What happened this afternoon that brought you to this place? Not the words you think I want to hear. Not the theological language of humility. Tell me the truth of it. What did you see or hear or feel that changed you? And more importantly—how will you remain changed when the morning comes and the world presses its demands upon you again? I will help you, Your Majesty. I swore before God to guide your soul. But I cannot offer absolution for words alone. Show me the substance behind them.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The flesh is weak, for sure. And I will say immediately that there is no single grand revelation that can ever guard me from hubris or pride. Sometimes I have insights, or you could call them revelations, and they show me something and they push me in the right direction. But the flesh is weak and this is not something that can ever be definitevely won, but is more like a constant struggle. At least it seems like that to me. And before I answer your question about what happened, let me stress that the very foundation for our every talk and confession is that I am honest with you. I do not guard my words or feelings. I find great comfort in this and I hope you share this as well. Even if it exposes my sins. This midday, I walked around the city by myself and struck up a conversation with an old saddle maker. He commented on how the council had spent months discussing with nothing to show for it while he had made more than forty saddles. I commented that I would like very much to "fix their saddle as well", and we continued this comparison. He made the distinction that he would never walk into a noble man's home and comment that his saddle is wrong and that he must fix it. A comment that struck home very clearly. It is not my task to change the church, and even if I did have exactlly the right reform, no one would listen or even accept it. I must let go. And my own drive for pushing for this reform I recognized for the precieved divine guidance and over confidence you have warned me about. I still do not know exactly what to do and I fully realize that wanting to change the world is potentially very dangerous.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: A saddler. God speaks through strange vessels sometimes. A Franciscan would approve—we believe the humble often see truths the learned miss. I appreciate your honesty, Your Majesty. And I note that you do not claim grand revelation or divine vision. You speak of a conversation with a craftsman, a simple analogy that struck home. This... this sounds true to me. More true than theological language would. You say this is a constant struggle. Yes. This is wisdom. You say insights do not guard you forever. Also wisdom. You admit you do not know what to do next. More wisdom still. All of this is good, Your Majesty. All of this suggests genuine reflection occurred today. But I must speak plainly. You have had insights before. After the Infantes' rebellion, you spoke of humility. After Father Tomás refused you absolution, you wrestled with your soul. Each time, genuine struggle. Each time, real growth. And each time... Each time, Your Majesty, the world presented new opportunities, and the old patterns returned. Not because you are evil or insincere. But because, as you say, the flesh is weak. So here is what I propose. Not absolution tonight. Not yet. Tomorrow you will complete your second day of reflection. And I will give you a task—not to contemplate grand theological questions, but something simple. Concrete. Tomorrow, you will attend the Council session as observer only. You will sit in the back, as you did today. You will watch. You will listen. And when your mind begins to say 'I could fix this' or 'If only they would hear my proposal'—and it will say these things, Your Majesty—you will note it. You will write it down. Every time. Every impulse to act, to speak, to fix. You will bring me this list tomorrow evening. This is how we test whether the insight of the afternoon can survive the morning. Not by your words tonight, but by your actions tomorrow. Can you watch the Church struggle and not intervene? Can you let go in practice, not merely in principle? This is not punishment, Your Majesty. This is medicine. The soul, like the body, heals through discipline and practice, not through single moments of understanding. You say you want to let go. Show me. Show yourself. Show God. Will you accept this task?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Of course, I do. And if I may ask father. You mention that I have had revelations before and then...the old patterns returned. Could you be a bit more specific? What did I do specifically?

roll.outcome: Cautious Doubt - Acknowledges words but questions sincerity; notes pattern of agreeing then reverting; asks pointed questions about what changed; reserves judgment

encounters.recap: Juan confesses his spiritual crisis to Fray Hernando after reflecting on a saddler's wisdom about not forcing unwanted help. The confessor remains skeptical due to Juan's pattern of reversing course after moments of humility, withholding absolution and assigning a practical test for the following day.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: This is how we test whether the insight of the afternoon can survive the morning. Not by your words tonight, but by your actions tomorrow. Can you watch the Church struggle and not intervene? Can you let go in practice, not merely in principle? This is not punishment, Your Majesty. This is medicine. The soul, like the body, heals through discipline and practice, not through single moments of understanding. You say you want to let go. Show me. Show yourself. Show God. Will you accept this task?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Of course, I do. And if I may ask father. You mention that I have had revelations before and then...the old patterns returned. Could you be a bit more specific? What did I do specifically?

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You ask for specifics. Good. This is what a man serious about his soul does. He does not hide from his patterns. He examines them. Let us begin with Rome, Your Majesty. Two and a half years ago now. You stood before Pope Martin, stripped naked, offering everything. Genuine humility. I witnessed it. I wept. The Holy Father wept. The cardinals wept.
