exchanges.text: This strengthens the argument. If Byzantines refuse anything else, Council has clear rationale for unified command. The question becomes: who?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The older German cardinal looks at Juan directly: 'Your Majesty conquered Granada. Your crusaders are disciplined, your accounting impeccable. These are facts. But Council will want to hear from others -- from Emperor Sigismund perhaps, who knows Ottoman warfare. From Janos Hunyadi who has fought them for years. Not opposition to Your Majesty. But proper deliberation.'

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_de_cartagena
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, the Granada model worked precisely because you enforced this from beginning. Spiritual formation, regular confession, chaplains with every unit. This is... unusual for crusades. But effective.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The older German cardinal: 'Unusual is... polite word. Most crusades recruit anyone willing to take cross. Murderers seeking absolution, younger sons seeking estates, adventurers seeking plunder. Your Majesty proposes excluding many who would normally join.'

exchanges.speaker: bessarion_of_nicaea
exchanges.text: From our perspective, we would rather have five hundred disciplined, faithful soldiers than five thousand rapists and thieves. Quality matters more than quantity.

exchanges.speaker: giuliano_cesarini
exchanges.text: And morally, His Majesty is correct. Crusade should not be vehicle for sin's continuation. But practically... this reduces numbers significantly. Council must weigh this.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: On financial transparency, there is more immediate agreement. The younger German cardinal: 'Yes. Absolutely yes. Every crusade has been plagued by princes enriching themselves from donated funds. Granada's accounting was extraordinary -- His Majesty returned entire treasury to Pope Eugenius. This should be standard.'

exchanges.speaker: giuliano_cesarini
exchanges.text: No objection from me. Funds given for crusade purpose must serve that purpose only. But mechanism for enforcement?

exchanges.speaker: isidore_of_kiev
exchanges.text: Gold must reach Constantinople, not disappear into princes' treasuries along the way. How do we ensure this?

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_de_cartagena
exchanges.text: In Granada, we had oversight committee -- His Majesty, Cardinal Capranica, Archbishop of Toledo. Every florin accounted for. Similar structure for Constantinople crusade?

exchanges.speaker: giuliano_cesarini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty has proposed three principles: unified command, spiritual standards, financial transparency. All sound. All controversial in different ways. All require Council approval through deputations. I will propose these to general congregation.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The older German cardinal: 'We will support in principle. Unified command will require debate about who. Confession requirements will face resistance. Financial transparency -- yes, we'll push for this strongly.'

exchanges.speaker: giuliano_cesarini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, you depart Basel soon to meet Emperor Sigismund. These proposals will take weeks to work through four deputations. Perhaps months. Can Castilian delegation continue advocating in your absence?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: My delegation will remain for as long as the council is in session. I will leave and perhaps if circumstances allow it, visit again.

encounters.recap: Juan proposes three structural principles for the Constantinople crusade: unified military command (with himself as candidate but deferring to Council judgment), mandatory confession and spiritual standards for all crusaders to prevent the crusade from becoming a vehicle for criminals, and strict financial transparency modeled on the Granada crusade's accounting. The delegates respond with general support but note practical challenges: the French will contest Castilian command, confession requirements will reduce recruitment, and enforcement mechanisms for financial oversight need development. German cardinals strongly support financial transparency. Cesarini commits to proposing all three principles to the general congregation.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: One more consideration to make, Cardinal. Remember that the Pope will probably call crusade earlier than the council will, meaning that the council will have to adopt the Pope's exact crusade text if the dual legislation system we discussed is to work. Maybe it is best if you test the waters in session in the council to see if both Pope and Council can agree on the same text for crusade. Then both can enact it and gain total legitimacy.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will also require the full text of the one reform the council has already passed. I want to read it for myself and later discuss it with the Pope as well.

exchanges.speaker: giuliano_cesarini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty... yes. Yes, this is the practical implementation.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The older German cardinal catches on immediately: 'Then both can enact it simultaneously. Pope issues crusade bull, Council issues crusade decree -- same words, different authorities. Neither submits to the other, but crusade has complete legitimacy.'

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The younger German: 'And Constantinople receives aid blessed by both Pope and Council. No questions about which authority to recognize.'

exchanges.speaker: giuliano_cesarini
exchanges.text: The crusade call is perfect test case. Less theologically controversial than reform decrees. Clear practical urgency. If we can demonstrate cooperation on this...

exchanges.speaker: bessarion_of_nicaea
exchanges.text: Then perhaps cooperation becomes possible on other matters. Your Majesty, this is brilliant. Not asking Council to recognize papal supremacy, not asking Pope to recognize conciliar supremacy -- asking both to work together on text all can accept.

exchanges.speaker: giuliano_cesarini
exchanges.text: I will test waters immediately. Not formal proposal yet -- informal conversations with deputation leaders. Can we agree on crusade text with papal representatives? What are our non-negotiables, what can we compromise on?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The older German cardinal: 'You have our support. This serves both reform and Constantinople. And frankly, if Council cannot cooperate with Pope on this -- on defending Christendom from infidels -- then we truly are lost.'

exchanges.speaker: giuliano_cesarini
exchanges.text: The reform decree on electoral procedures -- I'll have it copied for you tonight. It's... substantial. Twenty-three pages. Cathedral chapters must conduct free elections for benefices rather than purchased appointments. Detailed procedures, penalties for violations, appeal mechanisms.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_de_cartagena
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I can provide Castilian delegation's analysis of the decree as well. We've studied it extensively -- strengths, weaknesses, how it might be received in Spain.

exchanges.speaker: giuliano_cesarini
exchanges.text: And Your Majesty will discuss this with Pope Eugenius when you visit Rome after your wife's delivery?

exchanges.speaker: isidore_of_kiev
exchanges.text: How long before crusade call can be issued? Using this parallel approach. Constantinople needs aid by autumn at latest.

exchanges.speaker: giuliano_cesarini
exchanges.text: If we can agree on text quickly... Pope could issue within weeks. Council would need to pass through deputations -- six to eight weeks minimum, perhaps three months. But if Pope issues first with our agreement, Council's approval follows more easily.

exchanges.speaker: giuliano_cesarini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, this changes everything. Not immediately -- Council moves slowly. But you've given us path forward that I didn't see before. Common text, parallel authority, practical cooperation despite theoretical disputes. I will begin conversations tomorrow. Quietly, with key figures. Test whether this is possible. And I'll have that reform decree text ready for you by tonight.

encounters.recap: Juan proposes the parallel legislation strategy for the crusade call: Pope and Council should agree on identical text beforehand so both can enact it simultaneously, giving the crusade complete legitimacy without either authority submitting to the other. Cesarini and the German cardinals immediately grasp the strategic brilliance, seeing the crusade call as a perfect test case for Pope-Council cooperation. Bessarion calls it a breakthrough that could enable cooperation on other matters. Juan also requests a copy of the Council's electoral reform decree to review and later discuss with the Pope. Cesarini estimates the Council process will take six to eight weeks minimum but commits to beginning informal conversations immediately.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The meeting concludes with genuine energy and commitment. Cardinal Cesarini promises to begin informal consultations immediately. The German cardinals commit to pushing the crusade decree through their deputation. Metropolitan Bessarion and Isidore leave with renewed hope, planning to depart Basel within days with the seventeen Castilian crusaders.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_de_cartagena
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I'll have the electoral reform decree text copied for you by tonight. And I'll ensure our delegation continues advocating after you depart.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The seventeen volunteers are ready, Your Majesty. Marco Tornesi is organizing provisions for the journey. They understand they travel with the Greeks within the week.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The late afternoon sun slants through Basel's streets as Juan returns to his lodgings. The meeting felt like a breakthrough -- concrete commitments made, genuine enthusiasm from Germans and Byzantines, Cardinal Cesarini energized with a path forward. In the quarters, Fray Hernando has left the copied reform decree on the desk -- twenty-three pages of detailed Latin text about electoral procedures for cathedral benefices.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Roll Result: 19 -- Procedural Death. Despite the genuine enthusiasm in the chapter house, the Council of Basel's structural paralysis proves insurmountable. Cardinal Aleman's French radical faction systematically blocks the crusade decree in the deputations. Constitutional warfare consumes every discussion. The German delegation pushes hard but encounters resistance at every turn. Months pass in committee with no consensus achieved. The Council debates endlessly and passes nothing of substance regarding the Constantinople crusade. Pope Eugenius will ultimately have to act alone.

roll.outcome: Procedural Death: Germans push hard but systematic resistance from French radicals blocks progress in all deputations. Constitutional warfare consumes discussion. No crusade decree passed within relevant timeline. Council paralyzed by factional infighting. Pope forced to act unilaterally.

encounters.recap: A d100 roll of 19 determines the ultimate fate of the crusade decree at the Council of Basel: procedural death. Despite the passionate breakthrough in the chapter house meeting, Cardinal Louis Aleman's French radical faction systematically blocks the decree in the four-deputation system, turning every discussion into a proxy battle over papal versus conciliar supremacy. The German delegation's genuine commitment is insufficient to overcome Basel's structural paralysis. The Council passes nothing regarding Constantinople, and Pope Eugenius will have to issue his crusade call unilaterally. Juan's concrete commitment of 1,000 knights and 60,000 florins stands alone as Castile's independent action.
